articles.author: Tim Reyes
articles.summary:
Astronomers have reported the discovery of a star that passed within the outer
reaches of our Solar System just 70,000 years ago, when early humans were
beginning to take a foothold here on Earth. The stellar flyby was likely close
enough to have influenced the orbits of comets in the outer Oort Cloud, but
Neandertals […]
articles.title: A Star Passed Through the Solar System Just 70,000 Years Ago (Universe Today)

articles.summary:
(_Dartmouth College_) In the first US study of urinary arsenic in babies,
Dartmouth College researchers found that formula-fed infants had higher
arsenic levels than breast-fed infants, and that breast milk itself contained
very low arsenic concentrations.
articles.title: Baby formula poses higher arsenic risk to newborns than breast milk, Dartmouth study shows (Eurekalert)

articles.summary:
Alternatives to methylene diphenyl diisocyanate are more expensive but perhaps
safer for your lungs and more


-- Read more on ScientificAmerican.com
articles.title: Better Home Insulation Needed to Ward Off Chemical Exposure (Scientific American)

articles.author: Megha Bahree
articles.summary:
Five employees of companies controlled by four of India's most prominent
tycoons, including billionaire brothers Mukesh Ambani and Anil Ambani, were
arrested over the weekend in a case of corporate espionage that alleges theft
of documents from government offices, according to media reports.
articles.title: Companies of Several Indian Billionaires Embroiled In A Case Of Corporate Espionage (Forbes)

articles.summary:
Absorbent makes brain tissue bigger, enabling optical microscopes to resolve
features down to 60 nanometers


-- Read more on ScientificAmerican.com
articles.title: Diaper Material Brings Nanoscale Resolution to Ordinary Microscopes (Scientific American)

articles.summary:
BOISE, Idaho (AP) -- Egg-laying season has started at four breeding facilities
for captive California condors, North America's largest bird....
articles.title: Egg-laying season starts at California condor breeding sites (The Arizona Republic)

articles.summary:
WASHINGTON (Reuters) - Last October's explosion of Orbital ATK Inc's Antares
rocket may have been triggered when debris inadvertently left in a fuel tank
traveled into the booster's main engine, two people familiar with
investigations into the accident told Reuters.
articles.title: Exclusive: Orbital explosion probe said to find debris in engine: sources (reuters)

articles.summary:
A bushfire visible from space is raging just outside the city of Adelaide in
South Australia. The blaze has burned 42 square miles so far, an area about
twice the size of Manhattan. Five homes are confirmed destroyed, and dozens
more have likely been lost. This is said to be the worst bushfire in the area
since the Ash Wednesday inferno in 1983. More than 70 lives were lost in that
catastrophe. The #Adelaide #bushfire is still raging out of control tonight.
Check this amazing photo of
articles.title: Following Record Temperatures, Biggest Bushfire of the Summer Rages in Southern Australia (Discover Magazine)

articles.summary:
A new theory suggests the Higgs field varied in the early universe, offering
matter a chance to split off from antimatter


-- Read more on ScientificAmerican.com
articles.title: Higgs Boson Could Explain Matter’s Dominance over Antimatter (Scientific American)

articles.summary:
A reexamination of museum mastodon specimens provides evidence that that last
ones were gone from what's called the Beringia region well before any humans
showed up. Emily Schwing...


-- Read more on ScientificAmerican.com
articles.title: Humans off the Hook for Alaskan Mastodon Extinction (Scientific American)

articles.author: By TOM PEDULLA
articles.summary:
Itsaknockout was awarded a victory in the Fountain of Youth Stakes after
Upstart, who had finished first, was disqualified for impeding Itsaknockout
during the race.
articles.title: In Derby Warm-Up Race, a Favorite Is Disqualified (New York Times)

articles.summary:
What causes obesity? Advertising junk food to kids? Cheap soda? The demise of
physical education in public schools? Too much screen time? Or maybe, it's one
of the little boxes in this Obesity System...

articles.title: Is Our Focus on Obesity Holding Back Public Health? (Scientific American)

articles.summary:
KBG syndrome and its relationship with gene ANKRD11 have been added to
Genetics Home Reference. Web links to MedlinePlus, patient support web sites,
Genetic Testing Registry, ClinicalTrials.gov, PubMed, and OMIM are included.
articles.title: KBG syndrome (US NLM)

articles.summary: Adware pre-loaded on Lenovo laptops leaves users vulnerable to hackers
articles.title: Microsoft, Lenovo scramble over Superfish security flaw (CBS News)

articles.author: Seattle Times: None Given
articles.summary:
Seattle Times: For years, politicians wanting to block legislation on climate
change have bolstered their arguments by pointing to the work of a handful of
scientists who claim that greenhouse gases pose little risk to humanity. One
of the names they invoke most often is Wei-Hock Soon, known as Willie, a
scientist at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics who claims that
variations in the sun’s energy can largely explain recent global warming. He
has often appeared on conservative news programs, testified...
articles.title: Noted climate-change skeptic linked to corporate money (climateark)

articles.author: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR and CORAL DAVENPORT
articles.summary:
President Obama’s expected veto of the Keystone XL oil pipeline bill this
week, the third and most significant one of his six years in office, would
likely be followed by several others.
articles.title: Oil Pipeline Veto Expected to Be First in a Wave (NY Times)

articles.author: "Erika Gebel Berg" (nobody@acs.org)
articles.summary:
Biomaterials: The molecules form a deadly nanofiber web around bone cancer
cells while leaving healthy cells alone
articles.title: Self-Assembling Carbohydrates Trap Cancer Cells In A Cage (pubs.acs)

articles.author: Jennifer Viegas
articles.summary:
Florida once again tops the list of states where shark attacks are reported --
but it just may be because people swim there year-round.
articles.title: Shark Attacks on the Rise, But Fewer Deaths (Discovery)

articles.summary:
A faint star with an even fainter companion came close enough some 70,000
years ago to perturb distant comets in our solar system


-- Read more on ScientificAmerican.com
articles.title: Star Buzzed Our Solar System during Human Prehistory (Scientific American)

articles.summary:
Author David Quammen traces HIV from a forest in Africa in his new book,
investigating how it came to infect more than 60 million people

articles.title: The Origin Story of the Worldwide AIDS Epidemic [Excerpt] (Scientific American)
